ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A good understanding of demagoguery and the roots of populist leaders appeal.
A lot - this course made me question the efficacy of democratic government (I still believe in it) but starting with the premise that democracy may not be so great was very enlightening.
This course had me read many texts that were very related to the study of demagoguery over time and try to think through why demagogues arise and possible solutions to this problem.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No major weaknesses. The course has two main strengths: the subject material (you read seminal authors like Plato, Lincoln and Robert penn warren), and the prof. Bryan Garsten is one of a kind. Wonderfully kind and great at leading discussion.

Strengths: Professor Garsten is so smart and thought-provoking
Weaknesses: the readings were a bit unequal - some weeks were very short, other times we had a 300 page book

Strengths: I really like the way that Professor Garsten teaches and I feel that I learned a lot from him and the readings. I also really like the assignments. I felt that they were fair and enjoyable to do. 


Weaknesses: It was very hard for me to participate in class because I did not enjoy the dynamic of the people in my seminar as it felt like everyone in there had done DS and would speak about political philosophers who were out of the scope of our class which made it difficult to chime in about. It felt like the class was meant for a certain type of student and was very hard to feel like I was not an imposter during discussions even though I had comments that I wanted to share, I was intimidated. Also, at times, the reading load was way too heavy to reasonably get done in a week.

Great class! I personally enjoyed the earlier parts of the course bi more, where we discussed works by Plato, Hobbes, Weber, etc. Still, the later conversations about the media/social media were very interesting too.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think calling on students would be helpful because it is hard for some students to participate on Zoom. I also would suggest asking a question and having everyone go around and answer it so those who have a hard time unmuting to speak have an opportunity to share their thoughts when they may feel intimidated to do so otherwise.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. If youre interested in the manipulation of politics, and how political communication influences ideology, this course is for you.
Yes - great content, professor, and discussion!

I think I would recommend this course to some students but not others. I do feel like it was a course that was made for some students to be able to succeed more than others. For instance if someone had done DS or was very familiar with political philosophy I would recommend this. 
I was trying to get out of my comfort zone of courses by taking this course and I struggled with imposter syndrome frequently throughout so I would not recommend this course to someone who thinks that may happen to them.
Yes! I really, really loved this class.

I would absolutely recommend this course. I greatly enjoyed the seminar format, although like any other discussion section, some students participated more than others. However, the small size of the class and Professor Garsten's excellent ability to guide the discussion meant that even when we were not directly discussing the texts (which were well-selected), the issues brought up were very relevant and meaningful.
